refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns a string value of its argument.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The string() function converts an object to a string as follows:

listitem.para: An empty sequence is converted to an empty string.

A nonempty node-set is converted to a string by returning the string-value of the first node in the node-set. Note that the XPATH standard says that 'first' means 'first in document order' here, not 'first value returned'. For almost all queries, there is no difference between these two orders; it may be important only for node-sets calculated by so-called reverse-order axis. Moreover, the rure of standard is senseless if node-set contains nodes from more than one document. That is why the standard is violated here, intentionally.
A nonempty sequence which is not a node-set is converted to a string by returning the string-value of the first node in the sequence.
A NaN number is converted to the string 'NaN'.
Zero is converted to the string '0'.
Positive infinity is converted to the string 'Infinity'
Negative infinity is converted to the string '-Infinity'
Integer number is represented in decimal form with no decimal point and no leading zeros, preceded by a minus sign '-' if the number is negative.
The boolean false value is converted to the string 'false'. The boolean 'true' value is converted to the string 'true'.
An object of a type other than the listed above is converted to a string in a way that is dependent on that type.

refsect1.para: If the argument is omitted, context node is converted instead as if it is a node-set of one element.

refsect2.title: obj
refsect2.para: Value to be converted into the string

example.title: Examples
example.programlisting: SQL> select xpath_eval ('string (//*)', xtree_doc ('abc')) ; xpath_eval VARCHAR abc SQL> select xpath_eval ('string (//title)', xtree_doc ('Simple test')) ; xpath_eval VARCHAR Simple test SQL> select xpath_eval ('string(.) div 21', xtree_doc ('100')) xpath_eval VARCHAR 4.761904761904762 No. of rows in result: 1 SQL> select xpath_eval ('string(//title) div 21', xtree_doc ('100')) xpath_eval VARCHAR 0 No. of rows in result: 1 SQL> select xpath_eval ('string(//a) div 20', xtree_doc ('100')) Query result: xpath_eval VARCHAR 5
